great art is always untouchable. it's a flower that blossoms and withers away. the urge to preserve and "democratize" destroys the natural quality of art. democratization turns art into stuff. but there's nothing wrong with blessing people with the means to produce more pretty stuff, either. it won't make them artists. nothing can, but themselves.

if everyone can create decent visuals, with most people not knowing any better, visual artists will stop getting commissioned. but if everyone starts writing decently, people will stop hiring authors. but hah! authors are never hired anyway; they make their money by selling at scale or they don't make it at all via their writing.

there's no cost to replicating a book. the author will be more than happy to spread as many copies of her book as possible. but a commissioned artist cannot do that. they don't benefit from scale or commoditization. authors do.

but yeah, maybe small artists like painters selling at smaller scales don't wish their unique styles to get commoditized because of how rare their pieces tend to be, by design. there's only one of each.

i don't think movie directors making for millions of people will face any issues. and maybe that's true for successful authors as well. the scales at which each piece of work sells are extremely different. movies and books are made for millions; a painting is made for one buyer.
i'm just hallucinating at this point

there's no provably correct interpretation of a painting. in fact, paintings actively invite the opposite. so all the value lies in having the "original", which means most of the value lies in the artist, not the art.

but not everyone can discuss socrates or sartre by merely buying the books. so possessing/having the ability to discuss the best sci-fi or philosophy or fiction, still, in a way, is a costly signal. you have to read them. comprehend them.

but if the same happens with paintings, i.e., paintings get their own version of the printing press and we start valuing them for the content and not their provenance, their value will get commoditized in no time, because everyone can consume them by simply buying them.

ofc paintings derive most of their value from being the only one, real piece of art. painting is still done by hand and isn't scalable like books are. books have the printing press and aren't valued today for being the original copy or being "handwritten"

on the other hand, paintings can sell for millions, but i don't know great books selling for even 1/1000th the price.

when reality doesn't abide by my self-concept, i suffer.

no workout for two weeks? suffer.

writer's block? suffer.

didn't go to the latest hot joint in town? suffer.

an introvert attending a party? suffer. i'm an introvert, i'm supposed to suffer social events.

cinephile and watching a crap movie rake in billions? suffer. the masses simply don't appreciate good art.

someone tweeted out something cringe? suffer. this platform is going to shit.

i visit fancy restaurants and immediately integrate that into my personality/narrative

i go to the gym five times a week, and i immediately integrate that into my identity

i write regularly, and i immediately think of myself as a writer, along with all of its associated memes and aesthetics

i do x, y, or z, and now my personality is x-, y-, or z-coded.

every event defines me, there's nothing coincidental or accidental in my life. i'm god's chosen snowflake.
i suffer when everything is meaningful and everything has to fit into my narratives, one way or another.

till you see yourself as the doer, both compliments and insults will be univited guests at your house, and they'll never leave.

your thirst for validation will never end, because what you think is your self is nothing but a fictitious entity constantly propped up by the validation it manufactures by assigning a sense of doership to everything.

someone smart and influential says "your product sucks ass because <stuff related to product and market>"

what i hear: "this person thinks the product sucks ass. it may or may not be due to the reasons they cited, but it's interesting."

what you hear: "MY product sucks ass because I'M not doing a good job with a, b, c. maybe if *I* were smarter, more disciplined, worked harder, had that ivy league peer group, joined that course, *I* would be a better founder and MY product would be amazing."

what a depressed person hears: "my product is a FAILURE. I AM A FAILURE. i have ALWAYS failed. i'm a failed founder and a failed human. my girlfriend DUMPED me, my parents HATE me, all my friends are doing vastly better than me. i will NEVER be great. and i don't DESERVE anything."

there's no disease like excessive self-narrativization, where accidentally breaking a glass turns into

"i'm so careless",

which turns into

"i deserved my gf dumping me"

which turns into

"i'm a good-for-nothing, terrible person"

which turns into

"i need to change my life" - if you're optimistically conditioned

or

"i need to kill myself" - if you're pessimistically conditioned

the more self-obsessed you are, the more you suffer. depression is extreme self-obsession, and so is popular narcissism.

there is a center there that latches on to all incidental events and narrativizes the heck out of them. it's living with the crazy belief that everything that happens, happens BECAUSE OF ME. it's excessive meaning making; an incessant mythmaking, where the conditioned self tries to connect every event with the self.

reality is neutral.

hot take: it's highly likely that a writer who loves frameworks and measurement and attribution is not a great writer. this person is playing it too safe and doesn't understand what makes the best pieces of writing work.

and no, it isn't some mystical woo shit either. you can produce excellent writing even with sota llms. the only difference is a rational framework-oriented person is operating in a low-dimensional space and does not grok lots of other variables that make up the craft.

a major issue with prompting for creative writing is understanding how llms overindex on certain words and terms versus others. devs don't understand this as much as writers who use it often, do.

devs are trained to be rigorous in their asks, which is *precisely what you shouldn't be doing* if you want better creative output.

the sad part part about all llm discourse is that it's largely dominated by devs and their "frameworks". and creatives ‚Äî especially writers ‚Äî aren't interested in ai and think it's useless, which is dumb af.

so, writers who use llms regularly will be leagues ahead of devs in this regard. the latter simply do not understand how to supply a creative brief to an llm. their prompts are crap and will never lead to 99th percentile output, which llms are pretty capable of, even today, when you know how to prompt them.

it won't be a single prompt, but more of a conversation. but when done right, it will deliver more than what you had hoped for, which is the whole point of creative augmentation with an llm.

there's no need for any llm specifically tuned for creative writing, either. you can get great output even from sonnet 3.5 if you can cast the right magic spells.

- always be standing, or sleeping, rarely seated
- no cozy furniture in your work room
- always have something to fidget with at hand. ideally something that gets you moving. i have a tennis ball and a football
- work out at low to moderate intensity multiple times a day, rarely high intensity
- use breaks from work to do household chores. that'll keep you moving

equating writing with code and planning it like you'd plan your code misses what makes writing uniquely powerful. 

code is constrained by logic and demands deterministic outcomes. it must be precise and unambiguous to function. and even though beautifully structured code can be elegant, it operates within strict boundaries of what can be computed or executed.

writing has vastly higher degrees of freedom than code. a powerful piece of prose or poetry can mean different things to different readers, can gesture toward the ineffable, evoke emotions that defy categorical definition, create resonance through space and what remains unsaid, hold contradictory truths simultaneously, communicate through rhythm and sound beyond literal meaning, etc. 

it operates in a much higher dimensional space than code. with the best writing, the dynamic range is many orders higher and opens up access to the full spectrum of communication, including the parts that resist systematic representation.

but programmers have a tendency to reduce everything to simplistic prompt frameworks, and that rarely churns out great results.

by doing that, he pulls you into his own philosophy and way of thinking ‚Äî which is understandable, considering he's on a public podcast where the intent is to do precisely that. but now, if he also does it in his everyday conversations, it betrays a deep need for validation.

https://t.co/YtYsmHBLQA

never try to impress your peers. see what they're doing but keep them at an arms distance. the market you're serving is totally different from the koolaid your elite peers on twitter are drinking. 

and your peers are always elite, because good creatives have a natural tendency to always look up. but between where you're at personally in terms of taste and what your clients will need from you is worlds apart. 

peers are impressed by different things than your actual clients. and it's terribly easy to get sucked into an echo chamber where you're congratulating each other for things regular clients would never notice or value. clients don't care about the clever technique you used or how you pushed some philosophical or aesthetic boundary. they care if it solves their problem. and the solution they'll sign off on will often be terrible by your standards. doesn't matter.

observe your peers to stay current, but don't get sucked into their validation games. the moment you start chasing their approval, you've lost the plot. 

and you'll start hating your clients, which doesn't help.

the market is not for artists. no businessperson cares about your art. art is what you create when at leisure and without incentive.

if you understand this simple thing, you will save yourself a lot of jadedness and disappointment.

you don't need to transform failure into a "growth and learning opportunity"; it can simply be failure, its significance beginning and ending there.

no need to reconceptualize your weakness as a "hidden strength"; it can remain a weakness.

calamities befalling you aren't obligated to "build character"; they can exist solely as painful experiences that occurred.

üî∏when you have no desire to do something, that absence of desire is simply a fact.
üî∏calling this lack of desire a "problem" is your interpretation, not a fact.
üî∏for example, not wanting to learn how to code is just a fact, not a problem.
üî∏however, your interpretation reveals a deeper desire: getting a high-paying job.
üî∏this desire points deeper still to what you really want: money.
üî∏but even money itself isn't the final goal. it's what money gives you: safety, status, freedom, choices.
üî∏so, you want to feel safe, not learn how to code.
üî∏learning how to code is just one path to increasing your probability of feeling safe in the future.
üî∏there are many other paths, many other careers.
üî∏if you're keen, you can go even deeper: ask yourself what safety means and where it comes from.
üî∏by focusing on the root, you'll find more paths forward.
üî∏if you focus on a trending solution and not the root of your desire, you will close yourself to all other solutions.

i love tigers and feel they're absolutely majestic beings, much more so than lions, but let's be real. unless you lock both in a cage, the tiger is not winning this.

lions are called kings because they resemble kings with their harem and family.

tigers may be superior in every way, but they're lone kings, i.e., not kings.

kings don't exist in isolation.

not the right way to think about this.

who wins depends on

1. the terrain on which the fight is happening
2. who has more fighting/brawling experience
3. who can deliver a killer blow and end the fight immediately (huge asymmetry in odds if one fighter is famous for one-punch knockouts)
4. who can afford more injury (lions have a natural advantage here, i believe, as they are supported by the pride)
5. raw brute strength advantage

in any real world scenario, a lion wins hands down, because a lone tiger won't even engage if the lion has his whole pride to back him up.

that's the tragedy with tigers and bears. both are more lethal and demonic, but they are lone wolves. and we know what happens to lone wolves.

the emotion itself is sincere and valuable data, regardless of whether your conscious interpretation of its cause is accurate.

the pain itself is a truthful signal that something needs attention, even if your initial interpretation of what's causing it might be incorrect. just as it would be unwise to ignore or suppress physical pain because you think you shouldn't be hurting, suppressing emotions because you judge them as irrational or unwarranted prevents you from understanding and addressing their underlying causes.
the emotion itself is "true" as a symptom or indicator, even if the immediate interpretation or conclusion you draw from it isn't.
emotions are reliable truth-signals; they're fingers pointing to the moon. they may not necessarily reflect external reality as it is, but they do truthfully reflect your internal reality.

you don't have to trust the conclusion of an emotion. even if the emotion is due to a cognitive bias or past trauma, it still indicates the truth about your specific knots and hangups, which you need to process.

doing this will be more useful to you than any intellectual suppression of the emotion just because "it's wrong to feel that way."

emotions, while visceral and immediate, often arise from cognitive distortions. you might feel intense anger that seems pure in the moment, but that emotion could be triggered by pattern-matching to past experiences rather than the present.
this, however, doesn't mean that emotions are purely truthful signals that you should trust above all else.

your emotions are the most truthful and sincere phenomena you experience. you can distrust all your intellectualization and justification, but you can never distrust the purity of a visceral emotion. it's the purest signal of intent and motive.

there is only one absolute, incontestable truth: consciousness exists. you know, without doubt, that you are aware.

everything beyond this fundamental awareness is unprovable. the entire world ‚Äî including all people, books, events, and experiences ‚Äî could be happening within your mind alone. nothing except awareness itself can be verified as real.

once you grok this, everything becomes a reflection of yourself.

books and authors do not remain books and authors.

people do not remain people.

events do not remain distinct events.

they're all within awareness, which is the only constant. things and persons within it are mirrors showing different aspects of yourself. everything is perception and interpretation.

books and authors are merely reduced to words in this paradigm. it doesn't matter who wrote them, or if someone in passing said them, or someone compiled a hundred thousand of them in what you call a book.

what matters is their unique alchemy with you and how you naturally interpret and respond to them. every interaction reveals facets of your identity, i.e., relationship with other things, ideas, and people.

awareness has no definable characteristics and is inarticulable. but that's not the point. the point is to treat all experience as a mirror that reveals more and more of yourself to you.

both what you perceive, and how you interpret what you perceive are the entirety of self-knowledge.

i have just one major gripe against running (the jogging kind), even though i have personally felt its cognitive benefits: 

most injuries in daily life occur due to sudden forces or awkward movements that require strength and mobility to handle safely, and rarely have to do with a lack of cardiovascular endurance. a good example would be catching yourself during a slip or maintaining stability when carrying an unbalanced load.

pure endurance training doesn't prepare you for these.

so it's much more fruitful to combine some running with some form of strength training. otherwise you lose a lot of your muscle as your body optimizes for running and conservation of energy/fuel over longer timespans and tends to shed unnecessary muscle mass to become more efficient at covering distance ‚Äî which only makes you weaker and more susceptible to injury, not less.

also, never a good idea to overdo running or any other kind of exercise for that matter.

does a tiger think "i'm not an ideal tiger?" 

does a lion, or a bear, or a crocodile think they've not achieved their potential?

a lion doesn't scroll through instagram at night, comparing itself to more successful lions. 

a wolf never lies awake wondering if it should have chosen a different career path, if perhaps it was meant to be a solitary hunter rather than running with the pack. 

a cat doesn't read self-help books and listen to motivational podcasts to overcome its fear of water.

and although it's easy to interpret and appreciate all this as a more noble or pure state of being ‚Äî as if these animals have achieved some heightened state of being that we've fallen from ‚Äî the reality is they are what they are and cannot conceive being or doing anything else. 

they simply exist outside the realm of memes, beyond the infectious spread of ideas that both elevates and torments us.

our ability to question ourselves is the inevitable consequence of our capacity to imagine alternatives. we can conceive of a thousand different versions of ourselves precisely because we can hold abstract thoughts and build upon them.

when you watch a shark glide through the ocean with a magisterial and graceful dignity, or a snow leopard absolutely laser-focused on its prey while the rest of the world seemingly vanishes from its sight, you feel a twinge of awe and envy at its apparent certainty. 

but the shark or the leopard isn't free from doubt because it has achieved mastery, it's free from doubt because it cannot conceive of being anything other than exactly what it is. animals inhabit a world of pure, instinctual experience, untouched by concepts.

in our thought-riddled and confused state, we deeply long for this purity, simplicity, and clarity. but the only way is through.

humans are a fundamentally different species with infinitely generalizable software. and that's why a lot of evolutionary biology and arguments that compare humans to primates are such an obvious scam.

this is also why there's no such thing as an ideal human, only an ideal conception of a human, of which there are an infinite number ‚Äî all equally fictitious.

conceptualizing one's life and potential only leads to movie-brainedness, where life is spent trying to personify what one thinks is cool and impressive.

therapy is advanced domestication.

this is largely why most therapy fails. your therapist always has a vested interest in these games of society. so they'll subconsciously keep trying to nudge you towards the "good" and away from the "bad"

only a person who is beyond good and bad and sees reality absolutely clinically, without any moral judgments, is fit to do the job.

a corollary:

never do this truthseeking exercise with someone who has vested interest in you playing the game.

so, never do it with 

- your manager who has vested interest in you becoming better at the game
- your "mentor" who has vested interest in you forming an identity around their vocation
- your parents, who have vested interest in you doing things that increase their status in society

these people will always try to push you towards some preferred trajectory. all of it will be quite well-meaning, but ultimately harmful, because they will guide the enquiry in a way that nudges you towards the "right" path.

they are only useful to understand how to play the game well, if you know you want to play it. but you can't rely on them to tell you if you want to play the game or not. their answers will always be affirmative: "you should play the game, beta"

so, this exercise can only be done with someone who has no vested interest in you and has no interest in you being successful at any particular thing.

in other words, every game has its set of rules. you either understand those rules or you don't. if you understand the rules, you'll have more success in the game; and not being successful in the game implies you don't understand the rules.

it's not about you, it's about the game. 

do you understand the rules? 

if you don't, do you *wish* to understand the rules? do you *wish* to play the game? 

or do you only wish for its fruit?

if you only wish for its fruit, find another way to get it, which will have you understand the rules of a different game. but ultimately, there's no getting around understanding the game you're playing.

there's no point shaming someone's arbitrary constructs/identity/values. they're irrelevant. 

all that matters is you say you want to play this game. now let's check how true that is. 

if we find out that it is not true, as evidenced by your actions and behaviours, don't take it as a failure. you've actually discovered something true about your real intent and motivations, and perhaps have spent a lot of energy and time you'd have spent otherwise chasing untruths.

there's no you, bro. you're irrelevant. nature is absolutely transactional. there's only the game, and how well you understand its rules. and the more you truly wish to play the game, the better your understanding of the game will be.

my gripe with subjective questions is the answers will always latch on to their identity and personal value system. but there's nothing personal about it; it's all borrowed, and that misunderstanding is what's creating all this mess in the first place.

so it's much better to keep the subject's identity out of it entirely and keep it about the raw calculus of cause and effect.

"it has nothing to do with you, you are not abnormal, you just need to understand how nature works and be okay with how it works, because i did not invent gravity, or society."

the forever prevalent insincerity in this world:

"i'm not as ambitious, greedy, or desirous as you filthy capitalists. but i desire the same fruit, regardless."

such lack of self-awareness and understanding of how cause and effect works would push any sincere man to clap back with contempt and shame the other for being such a lazy, good-for-nothing loser.

but there are better ways to deal with this situation.

laziness is a terrible but obviously convenient explanation for anything.

the real intent in the accusation is to always imply a "should", assign shame, and try to domesticate another human into one's own conception and value system of the world.

my suggestion: everytime you're inclined to accuse someone of laziness ‚Äî especially when this person is insincerely complaining about something ‚Äî try replacing

"you're lazy"

with

"you don't want to do it. which is fine. but it's only fair that you're okay with all the trade-offs not doing it would entail."

choose understanding over shame, and all your relationships will improve.

"suck it up, buttercup", "stop being lazy", "stop coping" and such commandments can only ever apply to the self, never thrust on others.

if i really wanted to do it, there would be all the sucking up needed to do it, all my so-called laziness would vanish, and my cope would succumb to the raw force of my intent.

used on others, these catchphrases are nothing but shaming strategies.
